headline: Photos of the Day: June 26
summary: In photos selected Monday by Wall Street Journal editors, the Queen’s Guard assembles at Buckingham Palace, voters cast ballots in Mongolia’s presidential election, Muslims celebrate Eid al-Fitr, and more.

headline: The Senate’s Health-Care Hour
summary: GOP opponents will be held accountable if they ruin this rare reform moment.

headline: CFO Tries to Keep Cycling Company From Spinning Its Wheels
summary: Lisa Klinger has focused on fundamental financial processes—and not a quick spin to an IPO—in her tenure as CFO for Peloton.

headline: Zinke Plans to Boost Payout to Rural Areas
summary: Interior Secretary Ryan Zinke said his agency would award a record $464.6 million to more than 1,900 local governments to help offset the loss of revenues on tax-exempt federal lands in their jurisdictions.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for edition of June 27, 2017.

headline: U.S. Ramps Up Lumber Trade Spat With Canada
summary: The Trump administration added a new layer of duties on softwood-lumber imports from its northern neighbor, even as it said it still hopes to negotiate a settlement before the full bite of the penalties is felt.

headline: Shkreli Trial Off to Slow Start as Prospective Jurors Show Animus
summary: Jury selection for Martin Shkreli’s trial in Brooklyn federal court moved slowly as many prospective jurors balked at the expected four- to six-week commitment, and at least two dozen others were cut after expressing a strong animus toward the former pharmaceutical executive.

headline: Supreme Court Says State Playground-Grant Program Can’t Exclude Religious Schools
summary: The Supreme Court ruled that Missouri may not exclude a church school from a program that funds playground resurfacing, finding that discrimination based on “religious identity” violates the Constitution.

headline: Five Findings of the CBO on Senate Health Plan
summary: The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has released its much-anticipated analysis of the Senate’s bill repealing and replacing large swaths of the Affordable Care Act. Read five of the CBO’s top-line findings.

headline: Trump, Modi Move to Bridge Divisions
summary: President Trump welcomed Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to the White House on Monday, where they agreed to expand cooperation on combatting terrorism, stabilizing Afghanistan and overcoming trade differences.

headline: Supreme Court Refuses to Review California Concealed-Gun Restrictions
summary: The Supreme Court on Monday declined to re-enter the fray over gun rights, rejecting pleas to review a pair of decisions by different appellate courts that went in opposite directions over the extent of the Second Amendment

headline: The Senate Saves the 10th Amendment
summary: The health-care bill would liberate states to bypass ObamaCare rules and better manage Medicaid.

headline: Iran Won in Lebanon. What About Iraq?
summary: Officials in Beirut see no alternative but to accommodate the Hezbollah militia.

headline: 24/7 Banking Is 50 Years Old
summary: Before the ATM you had to get cash during ‘bankers’ hours.’

headline: The Market in Nosedive
summary: In the “flash crash” of 2010, shares gyrated between $1,000 and a penny, recovering minutes later. Other market meltdowns lasted longer.

headline: The Surprising Factor for Immigrant Success
summary: Those born in Algeria do better than those from Israel and Japan. Why? There are fewer of them.

headline: Anthony Kennedy, Culture Warrior
summary: Judicial decrees on difficult moral questions have made our politics bitter.

headline: A Unanimous Rebuke to Judges on the Travel Ban
summary: The Supreme Court lets nearly all of Trump’s policy be enforced as it hears his appeal.

headline: Religious Liberty Lives
summary: A 7-2 Supreme Court rebukes a relic of anti-Catholic bigotry.

headline: Bank Bailouts, Italian-Style
summary: Rome closes down two banks but saves their senior bondholders.

headline: Beijing’s Nobel Shame
summary: Liu Xiaobo will be remembered long after Xi Jinping is forgotten.

headline: Rabbi, 7 Others Charged With Public Assistance Fraud in New Jersey
summary: Four couples were arrested in Lakewood, N.J., Monday on charges of defrauding Medicaid and other aid programs, authorities said.

headline: Chris Hill Repents on North Korea
summary: Trump can learn from the diplomat whose appeasement failed.

headline: Arconic to Stop Selling Panels Involved in London Fire
summary: Arconic Inc. said it has stopped selling panels used on the exterior of high-rise buildings that are suspected of contributing to the spread of a deadly fire in a London apartment tower earlier this month.

headline: Program Creates a Path for Teens in Geriatric-Care Field
summary: A geriatric-care program at the New Jewish Home in Manhattan could help high-school students land jobs in the field, while fueling the fast-growing industry with a supply of workers.

headline: NotableQuotable: George Orwell
summary: ‘On this day in 1903, a future journalist named Eric Blair was born, better known as George Orwell.’

headline: Mexican Peso Rises to Highest Against Dollar in a Year
summary: The peso is leading this year’s rally in emerging-markets currencies that had fallen around the time of U.S. presidential election.

headline: Boston Judge Sentences Former Compounding Pharmacist to Nine Years
summary: A pharmacist involved in selling a contaminated pain medication that caused a deadly U.S. outbreak of fungal meningitis in 2012 was sentenced to nine years in prison Monday.

headline: New Zealand Cruises to Win America’s Cup
summary: Larry Ellison’s Oracle team failed to defend the Cup, falling 7-1 to the Kiwis in a disappointing result for the Americans.

headline: General Motors Lowers Outlook for Industry Vehicle Sales
summary: General Motors Co. expects industry vehicle sales to fall short of its original forecast for the year, the latest sign of a slowdown in the U.S. auto market after a record run.

headline: High Court Says Travel Ban Won’t Apply to Those With ‘Bona Fide’ Relationships
summary: The Supreme Court partially revived President Trump’s executive order suspending travel, but some with a ‘bona fide’ relationship in the U.S. may be exempt.

headline: Publicis CEO Goes to Twitter to Take Lumps, Defend Controversial Awards Ban
summary: Publicis Groupe’s new chief executive, Arthur Sadoun, held a Twitter Q&A session to answer questions about a move to build an internal platform called Marcel and temporarily pause award spending for the year.

headline: Gun Trafficker Gets 10 Years in Prison in Brooklyn
summary: A North Carolina man was sentenced to 10 years in prison Monday for his role in trafficking 33 guns from his home state to Brooklyn.

headline: Miranda Kerr Hands Over $8.1 Million in Jewelry to Justice Department
summary: Australian model Miranda Kerr has signed over $8.1 million worth of jewelry to the U.S. Department of Justice a week after lawsuits described how they were purchased for her by Malaysian financier Jho Low with allegedly misappropriated funds, according to her spokesman

headline: House Republicans Close to Deal Boosting Defense Spending
summary: House Republicans are nearing a deal on overall spending levels for fiscal year 2018 that would boost military spending well above the limit imposed by current law.

headline: Dollar Edges Higher
summary: The dollar edged higher Monday, brushing off a report that showed demand for long-lasting factory goods fell in May for the second straight month.

headline: Supreme Court Revives Suit Against Border Agent in Shooting Death
summary: The Supreme Court revived a claim against a U.S. Border Patrol agent who shot and killed a Mexican teenager standing across the international border.

headline: Supreme Court Decisions on Religion Hearten Conservatives
summary: Religious conservatives cheered the Supreme Court’s ruling on Monday that Missouri may not exclude a church school from a state program that funds playground resurfacing.

headline: In Travel-Ban Ruling, Who Won Is a Matter of Opinion
summary: The Supreme Court’s decision to review and allow partial enforcement of President Donald Trump’s executive order banning immigration from six predominantly Muslim countries inspired dueling narratives that hinted at a new round of litigation.

headline: Treasury Yields Settle at Fresh 2017 Lows
summary: Long-term U.S. government bond yields closed at fresh 2017 lows on Monday as the latest sign of tepid U.S. business spending added to concerns over the economy’s growth momentum and stoked demand for haven assets.

headline: Provisions of Trump Travel Ban Set to Take Effect
summary: A look at the various provisions of President Trump’s travel ban, and which features are set to take effect now that the Supreme Court gave them the green light.

headline: Appeals Court Deadlocks Over Challenge to SEC’s In-House Courts
summary: A federal appeals court said Monday that it was deadlocked on a case involving the Securities and Exchange Commission’s in-house justice system, an outcome that opens the door for the Supreme Court to resolve the dispute.

headline: Acute-Care Hospital Owner Enters Chapter 11
summary: Acadiana Management Group blames its bankruptcy on ‘stringent’ regulations

headline: Oil Prices Up but Mood Still Down
summary: Crude futures rose for a third consecutive session Monday, as investors weighed the relentless growth in U.S. oil output against efforts by major global producers to reduce supply.

headline: Steel Yourself for Trump’s Anti-Trade Moves
summary: Global trade’s in trouble, and investors don’t seem to care. One of the ironies of the election of a nationalist in the U.S. is that it coincided with what looked like a recovery in global trade.

headline: Connecticut’s Governor Strikes Tentative Deal With Public Employees
summary: Connecticut Gov. Dannel Malloy’s administration agreed to a raft of concessions with public-sector unions, including a three-year wage freeze, in a deal that would help close the state’s budget deficit, the governor’s office said Monday.

headline: German Pacifism Comes Under Fire
summary: The country is surprised its military faces danger in Syria. But what then does it think its military is for?

headline: Martin Marietta to Buy Bluegrass Materials for $1.63 Billion
summary: Martin Marietta Materials said it has agreed to buy Bluegrass Materials for $1.63 billion in cash, in an effort to expand its southeastern U.S. footprint and product range.

headline: Supreme Court to Consider Case Over Whistleblowers
summary: The Supreme Court agreed to consider whether employees who report misconduct at their companies are entitled to protections as “whistleblowers” if they report the alleged wrongdoing only internally, not to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Supreme Court’s Main Moves
summary: The Supreme Court weighed in on the Trump temporary travel ban and agreed to take a case on whether a shop can refuse to make a wedding cake for a same-sex couple, along with other moves Monday.

headline: In Unilever’s Radical Hiring Experiment, Resumes Are Out, Algorithms Are In
summary: To diversify its candidate pool, Unilever has ditched resumes and traditional campus recruiting. Its new process relies on algorithms to sort candidates and targets young potential hires where they spend much of their time: their smartphones.

headline: GOP Senators Add Waiting-Period Penalty to Health-Care Bill
summary: Senate Republican leaders added a provision to their health-overhaul legislation that would impose a waiting period on coverage of six months for people who let their insurance lapse, a penalty aimed at keeping premiums affordable by making sure healthy consumers maintain coverage.

headline: Draghi Says ECB Policy Has Helped Reduce Inequality
summary: European Central Bank President Mario Draghi defended the impact of the bank’s stimulus policies on Europe’s youth, arguing that keeping interest rates low had helped create jobs and reduce inequality.

headline: BMW Commits to New Jobs at U.S. Factory
summary: BMW is the latest auto maker to commit to new jobs at a U.S. factory following criticism from President Donald Trump, saying Monday it will create 1,000 American jobs through 2021

headline: ‘Raphael: The Drawings’ Review: Beyond the Brush
summary: An exhibition at the Ashmolean reveals how Raphael’s artistic genius transcended the medium of paint.

headline: Supervalu CFO Resigns
summary: Retail and wholesale food-seller Supervalu Inc.’s chief financial officer is resigning, the third industry executive to step down in the last week amid turmoil in the grocery industry.

headline: Amtrak Names Former Delta Chief as Railroad CEO
summary: Amtrak named former Delta Air Lines chief executive Richard Anderson as the new president and CEO of the national passenger railroad, which is grappling with a backlog of repairs even as ridership continues to grow.

headline: The Drawings of a Renaissance Master
summary: The drawings of Raphael reveal the artist’s unending search for fresh ways of defining his restless vision.

headline: Alphabet’s Waymo Hires Avis to Service its Driverless Cars
summary: Google parent Alphabet is hiring rental-car firm Avis Budget Group to store and service its self-driving cars in a deal that shows Alphabet’s vision of a network of driverless taxis is getting closer to reality.

headline: Europe’s Brexit Negotiator Urges U.K. to Show ‘More Ambition’ on EU Citizens’ Rights
summary: The European Union’s chief Brexit negotiator called on the U.K. to show “more ambition” in protecting the rights of EU citizens following the U.K.’s departure from the bloc after London laid out detailed proposals on the issue.

headline: Citi Taps Former Senior J.P. Morgan Banker for Advisory Role
summary: Citigroup has hired Karl-Georg Altenburg, a high-profile former J.P. Morgan Chase and Deutsche Bank investment banker as a senior adviser.

headline: Freighter Captain Says U.S. Destroyer Ignored Warnings
summary: The captain of a cargo ship that hit a U.S. destroyer near Japan earlier this month has said in a report that the ship sent emergency warnings as the American vessel suddenly cut across its path, according to a person with direct knowledge of the testimony.

headline: Anthem Says Senate Health Bill Will Bolster Individual Insurance Market
summary: Anthem Inc. said it believes that the Senate Republicans’ health bill will bolster the individual insurance market, an endorsement for the legislation as many other insurers have suggested it could undermine the marketplaces created by the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Trump Blasts Obama’s Handling of Alleged Russian Meddling
summary: President Donald Trump lashed out on Monday at his predecessor over his handling of Russia’s alleged meddling in the U.S. election and denied any collusion between the Trump campaign and Moscow.

headline: Cricket Bars, Anyone? Quirky Foods Take Center Stage at Gourmet Trade Show
summary: Protein bars made from ground-up crickets are among the tens of thousands of gourmet offerings at the 63-year-old Fancy Food Show at Manhattan’s Javits Center through Tuesday.

headline: How John Cena Became a Triple Threat
summary: The wrestler-turned-actor shares time-management tips for juggling movie, TV and music gigs

headline: Third Point Move Could Lead to Nestlé-L’Oréal Decoupling
summary: Is Nestlé’s stake in L’Oréal in play? Daniel Loeb is pushing the Swiss food giant to sell its $27.4 billion stake in the French cosmetics firm.

headline: Don’t Extend VA Drug Pricing, Formulary
summary: The VA and Medicare are two very different programs. Applying the rules of one program to the other could complicate health coverage for millions of Americans covered by either.

headline: Best Plan Depends on Individual’s Situation
summary: Those who choose Roth must have adequate discretionary income to boost current savings rates.

headline: Handing Terrorists New York City’s Anti-Terrorist Plans
summary: Manhattan Democratic City Councilman Daniel Garodnick will undermine public trust with his sponsorship of an absolutely ridiculous bill that will only aid terrorists.

headline: The Pentagon Should Deploy Against Waste
summary: We keep hearing about the waste within the military procurement system and other duplications red tape, and antiquated computer systems.

headline: Law Professor Herma Hill Kay Helped Usher in Era of ‘No-Fault’ Divorce
summary: Herma Hill Kay was the first woman to lead an elite law school, serving as the dean of UC Berkeley School of Law. Her expertise in family and antidiscrimination law made her a pioneer in legal teaching. She died June 10 at 82.

headline: Doctors Learn How to Give Patients the Worst News
summary: Physicians are trained in how to tell patients they are going to die through a simulation program where they act out conversations. They learn to maintain eye contact, be succinct and avoid getting defensive when patients or families get angry.

headline: Why the Fed Should Surprise Us More
summary: Sebastian Mallaby writes in the Journal that the Fed’s habit of calming the markets may be helping to set up the next crash.

headline: Voices: On Farm and Fortune: Planning for Succession in the Family Business
summary: : Daniel S. Miller, co-owner and president of Miller Financial Group in Iowa, says succession planning for family farms--and the future of any family business--require a big-picture perspective on the part of the adviser.

headline: Voices: How to Work With One-Income Couples
summary: Adviser Voices: Carrie S. Gallaway, managing partner and adviser at YorkBridge Wealth Partners in New York, says that when a client couple has only one income-earner it’s crucial to keep the non-breadwinner informed of the overall financial picture.

headline: Germany Warns Turks on Security Officers
summary: Germany warned Turkey that members of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s security detail facing arrest warrants in the U.S. wouldn’t be welcomed during next month’s Group of 20 summit.

headline: Philando Castile Family Reaches Settlement in Death

headline: A Turning Point for Commercial Property
summary: Commercial real estate prices are starting to roll over after reaching record highs, capping a long postcrisis rally.

headline: Why Chris Sale Never Shakes Off His Catcher. Like, Ever.

headline: Democrats’ Broad Challenge: Middle-Class Appeal
summary: As the Democratic Party tries to translate anti-Trump sentiment into electoral success, it might ponder why its grip on the middle class has loosened, Gerald F. Seib writes.

headline: Shale Produces Oil, Why Not Cash?
summary: Producers of oil and natural gas from places like the Permian Basin have been burning more cash than they produce for the history of the business and an expected turnaround this year is starting to look less impressive.

headline: U.S. Durable Goods Orders Fell 1.1%
summary: Demand for long-lasting factory goods declined in May for the second straight month, a possible sign of softness in the U.S. manufacturing sector.

headline: Why Jordan Spieth’s Tee Shots Didn’t Matter
summary: Jordan Spieth wasn’t good off the tee at the Travelers Championship, but it didn’t matter. He was that much better than the rest of the field in the other aspects of his game.

headline: Their Towns Overrun With Tourists, Some Italians Cry, ‘Basta!’
summary: Officials squabble over limiting visitors to holiday hot spots like Venice, Florence and Capri.

headline: Rio Tinto Rebuffs Glencore Again in Bidding for Australian Coal Assets
summary: Glencore suffered another setback in the bidding for Australian coal mines, after the commodity giant’s rival Rio Tinto said it would rather take a sweetened offer from a Chinese-owned company.

headline: Takata Counting on Car Maker Support to Save Its Business
summary: Takata says it will finalize its U.S. bankruptcy survival agreement in less than a month, gathering signatures from major car makers on a pact that pledges support for the effort to save its automotive-parts business.

headline: Supreme Court Weighs Major Issues on Term’s Final Day
summary: The Supreme Court could see a blockbuster day Monday, facing several major issues to resolve on the last day of its 2016-17 term.

headline: Easy Money Gone, Loeb Has a Tough Road at Nestlé
summary: A soaring share price and changes in the works before the activist’s arrival mean smaller gains and more time to get them at Swiss food company.

headline: Why Italy’s Bank Rescue Looks a Backward Step for Europe
summary: A sweetheart deal to wind down two small banks raises wider questions about state support for lenders.

headline: Rural Youth Chase Big-City Dreams
summary: Young people are leaving Iowa’s Mahaska County and other rural communities in the nation’s heartland to go to college—and not many are coming back.

headline: Credit Suisse Denies Charging Excessive Fees in Mozambique Loan Scandal
summary: Credit Suisse denied the allegation, saying the assertion that it took in $100 million for its role in securing the loans was “incorrect and misleading.”

summary: The New York delivery startup has quickly expanded its New York W-2 workforce and has raised $8.5 million in Series A funding.

summary: Puerto Rico, strapped for cash, is seeking private bidders to run and share in revenues from seaports, highways, airports, parking and other public services—a move critics say is short-sighted.

headline: Time the Music Stopped for Evergrande’s Debt Dance
summary: The world’s most-indebted property developer, China Evergrande, is testing investors’ patience with another huge bond issue.

headline: The 10-Point: Gerard Baker on the GOP health bill, a big bet on Nestlé, what will replace the phone and more
summary: A personal, guided tour to the best scoops and stories every day in The Wall Street Journal, from Editor in Chief Gerard Baker.

headline: Which Payment App Is Best for You: Venmo, Apple or ‘Zelle’?
summary: All the digital payment services bring similar benefits—not needing to carry cash or write a check. But there are distinct advantages and setbacks for some of the leading products as well.

headline: Google Could Be a Day Away From At Least $1 Billion EU Antitrust Fine
summary: The European Union’s antitrust watchdog will as soon as Tuesday hit Google with a fine of more than $1 billion and demand changes to the company’s business practices, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Is This a Leverage Problem: $73 Billion in Chinese Loans to HNA?
summary: Whether or not the ties between banks and companies like HNA amount to systemic risk, it’s clear the relationships are complex

headline: Fed’s Williams: Rate Increases Needed to Keep Economy on Track
summary: The main goal of monetary policy right now is “to keep the expansion going as long as possible,” the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco president said in the text of a speech to be delivered in Australia.

headline: Supreme Court Allows Partial Implementation of Trump Travel Ban
summary: The Supreme Court allowed President Trump to implement part of his temporary ban on travelers from six Muslim-majority countries and said it would review lower-court rulings that found the executive actions likely unlawful.

headline: Sprint Enters Into Exclusive Talks With Charter, Comcast on Wireless Deal
summary: Sprint has entered into exclusive talks with Charter Communications and Comcast as the cable companies explore a deal that could bolster their plans to offer wireless service, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Senate Health Bill Raises Uninsured by 22 Million, the CBO Says
summary: The Senate Republican health bill would leave 22 million more people uninsured in 2026 compared with current law and cut the federal deficit by $321 billion in the next decade, according to the Congressional Budget Office.

headline: Brazil President Temer Is Charged With Corruption
summary: Brazil’s top prosecutor filed criminal charges against President Michel Temer, marking a critical new phase for the corruption purge that has roiled Latin America’s largest country for the past three years.

headline: Utilities Shares Boost S&P 500
summary: Shares of utility companies and other dividend-paying stocks led the S&P 500 higher following tepid U.S. economic data. Technology stocks erased early gains.

headline: Supreme Court  to Hear Case of Baker Denying Cake to Gay Wedding
summary: The Supreme Court agreed to consider whether the Constitution’s religion clauses allow a bakery to deny service to gay couples.

headline: With 54 Million to Go, This Airbag Recall Is Never Going To End
summary: Japan’s Takata has filed for bankruptcy protection and agreed to sell most of its business. But it could go on for years supplying parts for the tens of millions of its potentially deadly air bags that still need to be replaced.

headline: China Court Sentences 16 Crown Resorts Employees to Prison
summary: A senior executive of Australian casino operator Crown Resorts drew a 10-month prison sentence in China after he and 18 other current and former Crown employees pleaded guilty to gambling crimes; 16 were sentenced to prison.

headline: Why Didn’t ObamaCare Make Us Healthier?
summary: Bernie Sanders inadvertently raises a critical question as Republicans pursue reform.

headline: Berkshire Hathaway Makes $377 Million Bet on Commercial Real Estate
summary: Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway has picked up a 9.8% stake in real-estate investment trust Store Capital, at a time when many investors are growing concerned about the health of the commercial real-estate sector.

headline: Nestlé Unmoved by Demands From Activist Investor Third Point
summary: Newly minted Nestlé Chief Executive Mark Schneider is facing the first big challenge of his short career in packaged foods.

headline: New York Assemblywoman Talks Trash in Race Against Mayor de Blasio
summary: Republican Assemblywoman Nicole Malliotakis is focusing her race against incumbent Bill de Blasio to become the next mayor of New York City on day-to-day quality-of-life concerns.

headline: The GOP Stand in Georgia
summary: A transcript of the weekend’s program on FOX News Channel.

headline: Liu Xiaobo Released From Chinese Prison Following Cancer Diagnosis
summary: Nobel Peace Prize laureate Liu Xiaobo has been released from prison early and is receiving treatment in a Chinese hospital after being diagnosed with late-stage liver cancer.

headline: China’s All-Seeing Surveillance State Is Reading Its Citizens’ Faces
summary: Facial-recognition systems crunch data from ubiquitous cameras in a vast social-engineering experiment. Petty offenders face public shaming.

headline: May Clinches Deal With Northern Irish Party to Support Minority Government
summary: U.K. Prime Minister Theresa May clinched a deal with a group of Northern Irish lawmakers that will keep her Conservative Party in government despite the loss of its Parliamentary majority in elections earlier this month.

headline: FBI Director Nominee’s Client List Could Hinder Oversight of Investigations
summary: Christopher Wray’s defense work at law firm King & Spalding, where his clients included New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie and Credit Suisse, could limit his oversight of some major investigations.

headline: Who Pays on the First Date? No One Knows Anymore, and It’s Really Awkward
summary: First dates multiply in era of Tinder, and those tabs add up. Some women are wary the fake ‘reach’ for the wallet won’t be turned down.

headline: Strains Emerge as China’s Dollar Debt Piles Up
summary: A fall in the price of bonds issued by China’s largest property developer, China Evergrande, last week is adding to strains in the market even as Chinese companies continue to pile up a mountain of dollar-denominated debt this year.

headline: Mescal Math: Why It’s So Hard to Profit From Tequila’s Smokier Cousin
summary: Mescal, a cousin to tequila, is rapidly growing in popularity, but the world’s biggest liquor companies are struggling to parlay its rise into substantial profits.

headline: Today’s Top Supply Chain and Logistics News From WSJ
summary: Delivering up-to-the minute news, analysis, interviews and explanatory journalism on logistics, supply-chain management, e-commerce and more

headline: When the Mailman Unwittingly Becomes a Drug Dealer
summary: Fentanyl and other synthetic narcotics are streaming into the U.S. through international parcels delivered by mail and private express services, fueling the opioid crisis and creating a daunting task for Customs and Border Protection.

headline: Why Apple and J.P. Morgan Are Chasing Venmo
summary: Big tech and finance firms are charging into person-to-person payments with little regard for making money, believing such services will be vital to getting and keeping consumers.

headline: Amazon’s Grocery Ambitions Spell Trouble for Food Brands
summary: Amazon’s deeper push into the grocery business threatens to further pinch packaged-food companies already coping with slowing sales.

headline: Troubled Air-Bag Maker Takata Files for Bankruptcy
summary: Takata filed for bankruptcy protection in Japan and the U.S. and said it would sell most of its operations to a rival, nearly nine years after it began a global recall of rupture-prone automotive air bags.

headline: Senators Lay Out Demands on Health Bill
summary: Senate Republican leaders pushing for a health-care vote this week juggled objections from all corners of the GOP caucus over the weekend, with issues such as Medicaid and insurance regulations remaining key holdups.

headline: What the Health-Care Vote Means for the Midterms
summary: This week’s expected Senate vote on the GOP health-care bill will showcase a partisan divide in states where Democrats are poised to play defense in next year’s midterm elections.
